learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate management and leadership qualities (including teamwork, collaboration and self-reflection) in all aspects of veterinary professional practice including communication with clients (including consultations), the public, professional colleagues and responsible authorities.

Recognise the importance of the One Welfare framework, the human-animal bond, and sustainable wellbeing and why these concepts are important for veterinary technicians to understand in relation to their career and self.

Demonstrate and apply acquired knowledge and skills in all aspects of veterinary technology in clinical practice, including animal behaviour, anaesthesia and analgesia, surgical nursing and preparation, radiography, general medicine, allied health, emergency/critical care and supportive care of clinical problems in animals.
Handle and restrain sick, injured, and healthy small animals, avian & exotics, farm animals and horses to perform a basic clinical examination and a range of clinical or diagnostic procedures.

Demonstrate an understanding of end-of-life practices, including the role and value of hospice and palliative care in veterinary practice and the veterinary technicians’ contributions to patient care, family support and grief counselling.

Engage in the development of individual clinical and non-clinical learning objectives, reflect on, and use collaborative (group) based learning to enhance knowledge and skills required for clinical practice.
Demonstrate understanding of, and respect for, Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander and global Indigenous peoples’ values, cultures, and knowledge.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment Sequence: Team Leadership and Consultation (Workshops)
assessments.due_date: Please refer to the course Blackboard site for individual Workshop Assessment due dates and submission instructions.
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Practical/ Demonstration, Presentation, Reflection, Role play/ Simulation
assessments.task_description:
Students are required to attend & engage in 2 Workshops in VETS3048 which will attribute 15% to overall grade.

Workshop 1: Team Leadership  (5% ) - Monday 19th Jan, 2026.

In-class assessment of engagement and completion of individual and group tasks.

Workshop 2: Consultation  (10%) - Dates 16/3, 20/3 and 23/3, 2026 (Cohort will be split between these dates in Groups TBA i.e. each student will attend only one of the days).

Students will be rostered to a workshop session and a marking Rubric based on individual performance is supplied on Bb.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass these assessments, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of any written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Students will undertake a written examination comprised of multiple choice questions and problem-solving questions to demonstrate an understanding of VETS3048 content. Examinable materials will be from any lectures, practical classes, tutorials from Week 1 to Week 5.

This will be an Inspera Assessment, invigilated on-campus digital exam which students in this course will complete using their own device. Further details, including an introduction to Inspera functionality, practice opportunities, and where to go for support, will be provided in the Blackboard site for this course during the semester.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment Sequence: Individual & Team Based Learning (TBL's)
assessments.due_date: Please refer to the course Blackboard site for individual Workshop Assessment due dates and submission instructions.
assessments.category: Performance, Practical/ Demonstration, Quiz, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
Students are required to attend and engage in 6 TBL Assessments.

TBL1: Anaesthesia 1  (5% ) - Monday 2nd Feb, 2026.

In-class assessment of engagement and completion of individual and group tasks.

TBL2: Anaesthesia 2  (5% ) - Wednesday 11th Feb, 2026.

In-class assessment of engagement and completion of individual and group tasks.

TBL 3: One Welfare (5%) - Wednesday 18th Feb, 2026.

In-class assessment of engagement and completion of individual and group tasks.

TBL 4: Pet Loss & Grief (5%) - Monday 2nd Mar, 2026.

In-class assessment of engagement and completion of individual and group tasks.

TBL 5: Radiography (5%) - Tuesday 10th Mar, Wednesday 11th Mar, Wednesday 18th Mar and Tuesday 24th Mar, 2026.

Each student will only attend 1 of the 4 sessions. In-class assessment of engagement and completion of individual and group tasks.

TBL 6: Leadership & Management (5%) - Tuesday 24th Mar, 2026.

In-class assessment of engagement and completion of individual and group tasks.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.due_date: Assessed during the internal rotation or submitted by the industry placement partner at the end of each placement
assessments.task_description:
Students will participate in SIX (6) weeks of Clinical WIL Placement at the UQ Veterinary Teaching Hospital (VTH), known as Internal Rotations and EIGHT (8) weeks of Clinical Extramural WIL Placement at various locations (External Self-sourced Placements). Some rotation/placement shifts will occur after hours and on weekends.

Internal

Anaesthesia/Surgery, ICU/ECC and VTH (e.g., surgery, radiography, reception, pharmacy, medicine, behaviour, A&E, equine)

Rotations are PASS/FAIL and must be passed to pass the course. The rotations will include weekend shifts and assessments are to be completed via an electronic marking system as per below;

- Performance feedback

  • Internal - minimum two per week (pass/fail)
  • Case logs - one per week (pass/fail)


External

CEMWIL Career Enhancement 1 (FOUR (4) Weeks - self-sourced), CEMWIL Career Enhancement 2 (TWO (2) Weeks - self-sourced), CEMWIL Career Enhancement 3 (TWO (2) Weeks - self-sourced).

Placements are PASS/FAIL and all must be passed to pass the course. The placements may include weekend shifts (dependant on the provider e.g., Emergency & Critical Care Clinics) and assessments are completed by the placement supervisor via an electronic marking system as per below;

- Performance feedback

  • FOUR - Week Placement:
  • 1 feedback at the end of week 4 (pass/fail)
  • TWO -Week Placements:
  • 1 feedback per placement at the end of week 2 (pass/fail)


*Veterinary Technology graduates must competently and independently perform a range of clinical and technical skills as they enter the workforce. Students will be required to complete a set of Core Skills during placements and rotations which are PASS/FAIL. Skills can be performed on a range of animal species or models. The Skills Assessor should be a university tutor, veterinarian, veterinary technologist/nurse or other staff member, including the WIL Provider, who is competent and regularly performs the skill. Core Skills must be attained at 'completed' level to pass the course.

See Information & Rubrics 2026 for further information on assessment criteria including the Core Skills on the VETS3048 Blackboard Ultra site.

Attendance on all rostered shifts during each clinical rotation/placement is required and will be monitored. This forms part of the professionalism criteria on the assessment tasks for each rotation/placement. Students are expected to remain until all cases are up-to-date and treated, and to take appropriate breaks as required to ensure workplace health and safety. Students should check in with their rotation supervisor prior to leaving at the end of any shift.

Absences from placement/rotation

Refer to Learning Activities > Additional Learning Activity Information in this course profile for the SVS policy and procedure for reporting absences and making up missed shifts. This applies to all internal rotations and external clinical WIL placements.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass these assessments, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of any written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The 'Performance Feedback' forms are completed via MyProgress across each week of internal rotations.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Conference Week: New Graduate Tips and Tricks
assessments.due_date:
24/07/2026 2:00 pm

Abstract due 2pm Friday July 24th 2026

**Conference Week timetabled from 27 July to 2 August 2026**
assessments.task_description:
Students will work in pairs to submit an abstract and deliver a presentation based on a common clinical case seen by new graduate veterinary technologists (a list of cases will be provided by Course Coordinators to which student pairs can allocate themselves). By preparing and submitting an abstract, and the delivery of a short oral presentation (15 minutes: 12 minutes + 3 minutes for questions/discussion), students will enhance their skills in information synthesis and summary, oral presentation and teaching skills. Conference Week presentations will be marked by staff examiners and will include peer assessment.

Students will also complete a log of key learnings from presentations attended each day as part of the 'Conference Week Placement' Assessment.

Criteria & Marking:

The assessment guide and task instructions will be available via the VETS3048 Blackboard site.  Abstracts will be submitted via Turnitin, Blackboard. 

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
Key Learnings submitted each day.

**Conference Week timetabled from 27 July to 2 August 2026**
assessments.task_description:
Students will participate in Conference Week (scheduled week of 27 July 2026). Performance is assessed through the submission of "Key Learnings" each day of Conference Week. Additional details are available on the VETS3048 Blackboard site.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: The OSCE will be scheduled during Week 1 of the Central Exam Block Semester 2, 2026.
assessments.task_description:
Students will progress through a number of stations where they will be required to perform tasks and demonstrate skills that have been learned/acquired during rotations and placements, which will build from Semester 1 theory and practical content. Students may also be expected to answer questions related to the task being examined in written or verbal form. All students will be examined on the same day.

Marks are awarded for successfully performing composite tasks at each station. Questions will relate to any of the below list of tasks. There will be compulsory PASS stations for the practical exam.

  • selection of appropriate drug/s and dosage calculations - COMPULSORY PASS STATION
  • anaesthetic machine check - COMPULSORY PASS STATION
  • endotracheal tube cuff inflation 
  • anaesthetic patient monitoring - problem solving - COMPULSORY PASS STATIONS
  • catheter placement - COMPULSORY PASS STATIONS
  • demonstration of injection sites (SQ and IM)
  • fluid rate calculations
  • admission procedures for surgical patients
  • surgical preparation of the patient - COMPULSORY PASS STATION
  • identification of routine surgical procedure preparation requirements e.g. clipping margins, recumbency, necessary instruments/equipment
  • identification of surgical instruments
  • cleaning & maintenance of surgical instruments
  • preparing & sterilising surgical packs
  • care and maintenance of clippers
  • gowning & gloving
  • x-ray positioning and radiation safety - COMPULSORY PASS STATIONS


If a student fails a compulsory pass station, they may be provided an opportunity to re-attempt. Any re-attempt will be scheduled in Week 2 of the Central Exam Block. Where a re-attempt is provided to a student, the maximum score attainable for that station is 50%.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
Conference Week

Student clinical presentations / tutorials, and workshops. Hands-on workshops. Attendance is compulsory for ALL days.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Conference Week Student clinical presentations / tutorials, and workshops. Hands-on workshops. Attendance is compulsory for ALL days.

learning_activities.topic:
Animal & Human Wellbeing Module

A series of lectures, Tutorials and TBL's based on principles of the One Welfare Framework. Includes lectures and tutorials that cover animal welfare, human wellbeing and environmental welfare as well as a module on Cultural Awareness and Capabilities in Veterinary Practice.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: Animal & Human Wellbeing Module A series of lectures, Tutorials and TBL's based on principles of the One Welfare Framework. Includes lectures and tutorials that cover animal welfare, human wellbeing and environmental welfare as well as a module on Cultural Awareness and Capabilities in Veterinary Practice.

learning_activities.topic:
Radiography for the Veterinary Technologist

A series of lectures and practicals and TBL to enable the student to identify and apply the principles of x-ray production, radiation safety, veterinary licensing, and care and maintenance of x-ray machines and other radiographic equipment.


Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Radiography for the Veterinary Technologist A series of lectures and practicals and TBL to enable the student to identify and apply the principles of x-ray production, radiation safety, veterinary licensing, and care and maintenance of x-ray machines and other radiographic equipment.

learning_activities.topic:
Anaesthesia for the Veterinary Technologist

Series of lectures, practical and TBL classes covering principles of veterinary anaesthesia, anaesthesia equipment, planning and patient monitoring.

There will be practical classes dedicated to anaesthesia and monitoring the anaesthetised patient.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Anaesthesia for the Veterinary Technologist Series of lectures, practical and TBL classes covering principles of veterinary anaesthesia, anaesthesia equipment, planning and patient monitoring. There will be practical classes dedicated to anaesthesia and monitoring the anaesthetised patient.

learning_activities.topic:
Avian & Exotics Module

A series of lectures and practicals on reptile, avian and native fauna nursing and practical classes covering handling, restraint and clinical techniques used in veterinary practice.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Avian & Exotics Module A series of lectures and practicals on reptile, avian and native fauna nursing and practical classes covering handling, restraint and clinical techniques used in veterinary practice.

learning_activities.topic:
Leadership & Management

A series of lectures and TBL focusing on types of leadership, good leadership and management qualities for Veterinary Technologists.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Leadership & Management A series of lectures and TBL focusing on types of leadership, good leadership and management qualities for Veterinary Technologists.

learning_activities.topic:
Internal Clinical WIL Placements

Students will participate in six (6) weeks of compulsory internal clinical rotations at the UQ Veterinary Medical Centre


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: Internal Clinical WIL Placements Students will participate in six (6) weeks of compulsory internal clinical rotations at the UQ Veterinary Medical Centre

learning_activities.topic:
External Clinical WIL Placements

Students will participate in eight (8) weeks of compulsory external clinical placements at various locations. Placement sites may include research facilities, shelter organisations, general practices, livestock enterprises, mixed practices, equine practices, after hours emergency centres, and other facilities of interest.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
learning_activities.topic_description: External Clinical WIL Placements Students will participate in eight (8) weeks of compulsory external clinical placements at various locations. Placement sites may include research facilities, shelter organisations, general practices, livestock enterprises, mixed practices, equine practices, after hours emergency centres, and other facilities of interest.
